"I mean, look. The background is a fish market, and he's staring straight into the camera lens. Do you really think the guild leader didn't know they were being photographed by Mackerel?"
"..."
"Didn't they go to the fish market to confront him in the first place? Knowing the guild leader's personality, he would've made a scene and forced the guy to delete the picture. But he allowed it, didn't he?"
Bae Won-woo's dazed eyes seemed to wander in the air. Now that he thought about it, Lee Sa-young had been acting strange when they visited his house. Fresh out of the shower, wearing only a bathrobe, he clung to J. J, usually so indifferent, had been unusually devoted to Lee Sa-young.
The part of his brain that had been on strike for 364 out of 365 days suddenly started working hard today. He felt like he had stumbled onto something he wasn't supposed to know.
Bae Won-woo staggered to his feet.
"...Ji-soo."
"Yes?"
A look of determination crossed his face.
"I'm heading into a dungeon. Tell anyone who asks that I'm not here."
***
"Ahaha, staying back was worth it~ I even get to see pictures like this."
The lightly tossed newspaper fluttered to the ground. The gray paper soaked through with bright red.
A bloodstained, straight finger picked up a takeaway cup. The hand's owner was perched atop the corpse of a massive monster. White, disheveled hair blew in the wind. Gyu-Gyu, after taking a long sip of coffee, looked down with a smiling face.
"Has the civil servant seen this article yet?"
Standing a bit away, untouched by the blood, Jung Bin looked up.

chapters.title: Chapter 174: Wavelength
chapters.content:
Chapter 174: Wavelength
A slightly awkward expression showed through Jung Bin's usual gentle smile. He covered his mouth with a fist and cleared his throat before slowly nodding.
"Yes, I've seen it."
"What do you think? You know both of them, don't you~"
"Haha, that's not something I should comment on."
Gyu-Gyu bit down on the straw, showing his teeth as he chewed on it.
"Eeh~? Is there really something going on between them? All the hunters in the world are curious."
Jung Bin didn't answer and maintained his smile. After observing Jung Bin for a while, Gyu-Gyu shrugged as if he was losing interest. He tossed the empty takeaway cup behind him with a flick.
"Ah~ boring."
Clang—
Cracks began to form in the air as if a thin fracture had split open. Beyond the rift was a wasteland covered in white ash. Soon, a white light burst from within, and it scattered into fine ash. Gyu-Gyu balanced himself on one foot atop the corpse before standing up straight.
"Up we go."
Jung Bin scanned the surroundings. As the rift vanished, the piles of monsters around them also began to disintegrate into ash, one by one. Even the monster beneath Gyu-Gyu's feet turned to ash. He lightly jumped to the ground, stretching his neck and rolling it from side to side.
"Fish market, huh. It's been a while since I visited..."
Gyu-Gyu, who usually left the country as soon as his business was done, had been staying in Korea unusually long. Even though the task of tracking J had ended with his own appearance. Clearly, what had changed his mind was the Day of Change. The day he pierced through that massive whale in one blow...
Jung Bin, watching Gyu-Gyu move about busily, finally spoke up.
"How have you been lately?"
"Sudden interest in my life? Just living as usual."
"I heard you've been attending Sunday services regularly..."
"Ugh. Where'd you hear that?"
"Your picture was plastered right on the homepage of your father's church. It was hard to miss."
Son of a pastor, Ban Gyu-min. Hunter alias: Gyu-Gyu. His photo, prominently displayed on his father's church homepage, had become somewhat famous. Jung Bin had stifled a laugh the first time his team had shown him that picture.
It was hard not to, given the sight of someone standing out by a whole head among the others, awkwardly smiling and giving a thumbs-up. Even more so in a choir robe.
"I told them not to post that..."
For once, Gyu-Gyu scratched his cheek with an embarrassed expression. Jung Bin added with his usual gentle tone.
"You looked like quite the dutiful son."
"Ugh. If you've got something to say, just get it over with. I've got other places to be."
"Alright. Will you be attending the upcoming General Assembly?"
"Wow... So you came all the way out here to ask me that?"
Gyu-Gyu stuck out his tongue, pretending to gag in disgust. He then scratched his messy hair, grumbling.
"Why would I go? It's a hassle, and I know the director will just chew me out."
"But this meeting is important. Haven't you noticed the recent unsettling atmosphere?"
"..."
Gyu-Gyu continued to stare at Jung Bin with his ever-present smile, waiting for him to reveal his cards first. Jung Bin fiddled with the earpiece in his ear and finally spoke.
"Public distrust of hunters is growing by the day. That's what this meeting is about."
"So, everyone's gathering to scheme about how to get back into people's good graces? Hmm~"
Gyu-Gyu folded his arms, pretending to think deeply, before grinning.
"Not going!"
"Are you really not coming? You'll regret it."
"Not going~ I'd rather dive into Lake Baikal."
"That's unfortunate."
Jung Bin let out an exaggerated sigh, making sure Gyu-Gyu could hear it. He turned around with deliberately heavy footsteps. His voice, though soft, was just loud enough to be overheard.
"I heard J is personally attending this time..."
"..."
"Well, I can't force you to come. I'll be heading off then, I need to pick up Hong Ye-seong as well."
He had barely taken two steps when— whoosh! A thin vine shot out from behind, wrapping itself around Jung Bin's wrist. Jung Bin calmly began untangling the vine with his other hand, thread by thread.
"Aren't you headed to Lake Baikal?"
"Well, it's not like I'm dying to go."
The vine that had lightly coiled around his wrist now bloomed into a small, white wildflower. Jung Bin glanced back. Gyu-Gyu, half-turned away, was pretending to look at his phone. The vine had extended from the ground beneath Gyu-Gyu's feet. Looking up, Gyu-Gyu gave a sly smile.
"I was just thinking I'd check the schedule~"
***
Cha Eui-jae blinked for a moment, lost in the blinding white light that filled his vision.
Blurred figures rushed past him, too busy to notice. Once again, he found himself standing in the hallway of the old Awakened Management Bureau. He was standing in front of a door, his hand already reaching for the doorknob. Cha Eui-jae looked up and read the nameplate next to the door.
Director's Office. This was Ham Seok-jeong's room.
'Is this a memory of meeting Ham Seok-jeong?'
What kind of information could he extract from their conversation? It would be nice to find a clue about the apocalypse. His hand, which was reaching for the doorknob, hesitated. Cha Eui-jae took a step back from the door.
Right next to the Director's Office was another black door.
'Was there a door like that before?'
It was a door that did not exist in 'Cha Eui-jae's' memory. The door, which had appeared suddenly, strangely caught his attention. There was no nameplate on it. From the gap beneath the door, a black energy seeped out, undulating slightly. It felt oddly familiar.
'What is this?'
Someone whispered; Open the door. As if hypnotized, Cha Eui-jae reached out and gripped the doorknob. It was cold enough to send chills through his body. Slowly, he turned the knob. Creak— the door opened more easily than expected. Cha Eui-jae poked his head in to look inside. Pitch-black darkness greeted him.
'This is strange.'
He had read through 'Cha Eui-jae's' memories several times using the watch, but this was the first time an anomaly like this occurred. Has something changed? What could have caused this shift? The only thing different between then and now was—
'Lee Sa-young woke up...'
Thud. The space trembled. A powerful force pushed him through the door. Instinctively, he tried to resist, but the force was too strong for him to fight. He was helplessly pushed into the center of the darkness.
Bang! The door slammed shut behind him. Cha Eui-jae stared into the void with an incredulous expression.
'Damn it, did I just get pushed so easily?'
He clenched his fist, then opened it again, something felt off.
'...Wait, what?'
The power he had always felt as his own was gone. He hadn't realized how weak he had been before awakening. He felt disoriented, like an ant among giants. He stared blankly into the darkness.
'Cha Eui-jae' whispered; This isn't mine, that's why.
'What are you talking about...?'
Then, it happened.
In the empty void where nothing could be seen or heard, a voice echoed.
"...Did you say you turned back time?"
A voice, deep and low, more like a beast than a human. Creak, creak, the sound of footsteps on a wooden floor. Clatter, the sound of a drawer opening. An old clock floated into the air.
"Then, that means I can turn it back too..."
"..."
When Cha Eui-jae opened his eyes again, pitch-black darkness and a strange sense of being watched greeted him.
Before he could grasp his surroundings, he jolted upright, instinctively feeling his face. The mask was gone.
What is this? Where am I? The eerie presence continued to track his every move. It made no effort to hide itself. Just as Cha Eui-jae was about to throw a punch in the direction of the unseen presence, a familiar voice spoke.
"You don't need to be so startled."
It was Lee Sa-young's voice. Click— the sound of a button being pressed. A faint reddish light flickered on. Squinting, Cha Eui-jae looked around and saw the familiar room he had been visiting for months— Lee Sa-young's room.
Next to it, in the chair Cha Eui-jae often sat in, was Lee Sa-young, now casually seated with his legs crossed. Sensing his gaze, Lee Sa-young unfolded his arms.
"Looks like I woke you up."
"..."
"Did you have a good dream?"
"...You."
Cha Eui-jae stared at him, his shadowed face showing a flicker of recognition in his blinking eyes. Eyes that reflected everything like a mirror. He clenched his fist tightly.
"You're not him."
"Yes... you're right."
Surprisingly, Lee Sa-young agreed lightly.
"You woke up after two days."
"What?"
Two days? It was hard to believe. He instinctively tried to check the time, but there was no way to do so in this room— he had cleared everything out. Even his phone was gone.
Right, the watch. He raised his wrist, but his wrist was also bare.
"Looking for this?"
"..."
The watch was now in Lee Sa-young's hand. His black fingers were fiddling with it.
"It's pretty worn out."
"..."
"Yet, somehow, it still works."
Was he telling the truth or lying? Cha Eui-jae tried to read something from his expression, but his face was as blank as ever. That expressionlessness made him more anxious than anything. The Lee Sa-young he knew, after all, was always quite expressive.
Gazing at Cha Eui-jae, Lee Sa-young tapped his temple lightly.
"Seemed like you were having an interesting dream."
"..."
"How was it?"
A void entangled in the end of a long dream. A faintly familiar voice that had been heard. The owner of that voice was unmistakably Lee Sa-young. A mechanical smile spread across his face, devoid of mockery, joy, or any other emotion.

chapters.title: Chapter 175: Wavelength
chapters.content:
Chapter 175: Wavelength
Cha Eui-jae clenched and unclenched his hand. The strength that had disappeared had fully returned. A strange door that suddenly appeared in 'Cha Eui-jae's' memory. A voice he had never heard in Cha Eui-jae's memory, yet felt familiar. Cha Eui-jae tried to recall. The voice growled like a beast...
"Cha Eui-jae."
It was similar to what he'd heard in the fragment Yoon Ga-eul had shown him. Lee Sa-young was still sitting there, unmoving, smiling. It was an eerily precise smile. Everything about him seemed inhuman.
Should he neutralize him first? Cha Eui-jae cracked his knuckles. And right after—
Bang!
Cha Eui-jae shot forward, kicked the chair, and grabbed Lee Sa-young's throat, climbing on top of him. Thud, Lee Sa-young's head hit the floor. Tap, tap, tap... The watch fell from his wrist and rolled away.
Despite being pinned to the floor and choked, Lee Sa-young didn't resist. His smile didn't falter. Cha Eui-jae felt the urge to cover that face.
Lee Sa-young parted his lips.
"Stop it... I didn't do this to fight."
The skin under his palms felt cold, yet there was a faint, light pulse. Cha Eui-jae glanced sideways. Should he break his legs first? Even if he did, Nam Woo-jin could fix them...
Lee Sa-young whispered.
"I have to... test everything. This is the last chance."
"..."
Lee Sa-young reached up and cautiously covered Cha Eui-jae's hand that was choking him. His touch was cold. Cha Eui-jae tightened his grip on Lee Sa-young's neck.
"What do you want?"
"Oh, what I want...?"
The muscles in his neck trembled slightly. Lee Sa-young was laughing. Soft coughs punctuated by a delicate laugh escaped. Once he started laughing, it went on for quite a while before it finally ceased. Lee Sa-young tickled the back of Cha Eui-jae's hand with his fingers.
"Let's sleep together."
"...What?"
Cha Eui-jae doubted his ears. Did he hear that right? But Lee Sa-young stared up at him, still smiling. His long eyelashes fluttered. A dizzying fragrance wafted through the air.
"You checked for yourself just now."
Lee Sa-young tapped his head with his fingers. It was a rough action, with no regard for his own body. Cha Eui-jae almost grabbed his hand but stopped. Lee Sa-young continued, unbothered, in a slow voice.
"Your dreams and my dreams are connected now. Thanks to the watch."
"..."
"Aren't you curious? About what only I know..."
A warden who had watched the end for a long time. What the end is, how it comes, and why they failed. No one would know better than Lee Sa-young. It was a tempting offer.
Cha Eui-jae stared into the violet eyes nestled between Lee Sa-young's disheveled hair. The eyes still reflected everything about him. No emotions, no opinions. Just reflecting. When Cha Eui-jae tightened his grip, a small groan escaped Lee Sa-young's lips.
After a moment, Cha Eui-jae loosened his grip slightly, allowing him to breathe. A fit of coughing followed. Cha Eui-jae felt the muscles tremble beneath his hand and asked in a low voice.
"This would all be over if you just told me. Why bother with the extra steps?"
"Oh, that's... no fun."
"What are you... You told me this is the last chance."
"I did..."
"If you miss this chance, we're all dead. You, me, everyone."
"I know..."
"And fun is still important to you?"
"What... isn't important?"
Lee Sa-young blinked slowly. His violet eyes had faded to a pale lilac. Deep in his soft-colored eyes, a white flame flickered. Cha Eui-jae, entranced, stared at the flame. Lee Sa-young muttered.
"I wandered alone for such a long time."
"..."
"And now... I finally feel alive..."
The black hands gripped the hands that choked him and squeezed. Cha Eui-jae snapped back to his senses and opened his eyes wide. Lee Sa-young barely whispered in a strained voice.
"Choke me harder. This feels good..."
A smile crept onto the face that had shown no emotion before.
A twisted smile. He was genuinely enjoying this.
A chill ran down Cha Eui-jae's spine. The sensation left him shivering as he yanked his hands away, shaking them furiously. Lee Sa-young clicked his tongue in disappointment. Cha Eui-jae was appalled.
'Is he really insane?'
The black fingers tapped against Cha Eui-jae's hand like the legs of a spider. He shuddered. Lee Sa-young burst into laughter.
"It's good for both of us, isn't it? Didn't you want to choke me?"
"Stop making me sound like a pervert!"
"Really? That's a shame..."
Lee Sa-young rubbed his neck, where Cha Eui-jae's handprint was still clearly visible. Cha Eui-jae swallowed hard.
Damn. Wasn't there supposed to be some meeting or something? Lee Sa-young shrugged.
"Weren't you digging through memories, trying to find something..."
"..."
"Think about it. I'm fine with whatever... Hyung."
And as soon as Eui-jae heard that word—
Smack!
He couldn't hold back and threw a punch.
Lee Sa-young's lilac eyes rolled back, and his body went limp. Cha Eui-jae, panting, unclenched his fist, his hand pressing against Lee Sa-young's chest. Luckily, his instincts had kicked in, and he had pulled his punch. His pulse was still beating normally.
Cha Eui-jae's hand trembled uncontrollably. He wiggled his fingers, the lingering sensation of Lee Sa-young's touch still vivid.
'What the hell? Is he a real pervert?'
What? Sleep together? Choke him? Is he seriously insane? Maybe he'd been wandering so long that he lost his mind.
Cha Eui-jae barely swallowed the scream rising in his throat. His heart pounded as if he'd run a marathon. Whether it was anger, shock, or excitement, he couldn't tell.
'Lee Sa-young is not in his right mind.'
Now, he missed the Lee Sa-young he knew. The bratty but somewhat endearing Lee Sa-young. Cha Eui-jae bowed his head, resting his forehead on Lee Sa-young's chest. His voice trembled.
"Hey, hey, wake up, Lee Sa-young..."
"..."
"Come on, don't just leave me hanging here..."
"..."
"You've slept enough!"
At Cha Eui-jae's shout, the body beneath him stirred. A small groan followed. Cha Eui-jae jerked his head up. Lee Sa-young, groaning as if in pain, held his head and blinked. His handsome face twisted in a grimace.
"What the hell..."
Lee Sa-young propped himself up on his elbows, bringing their faces closer.
"When did I... why are we like this... wait."
He narrowed his eyes and scanned Cha Eui-jae's face, tilting his head. His hand shot out, cupping Cha Eui-jae's chin and cheek. Lee Sa-young examined his face, frowning.
"Why is your face so red... do you have a fever?"
"My face?"
"Wait a minute..."
Lee Sa-young hesitated and clutched his head again, right where Cha Eui-jae had punched him. Cha Eui-jae averted his gaze. He looked like a dog who had done something wrong. Lee Sa-young blinked.
"Hyung."
"...Yeah."
"Did you hit me?"
"...No."
"Wait, then... why does my neck..."
Lee Sa-young rubbed his neck and cleared his throat. It was exactly where Cha Eui-jae had choked him. Cha Eui-jae turned his head further, almost looking over his shoulder now. Lee Sa-young tilted his head.
"Hyung."
"..."
"You know, don't you?"
Cha Eui-jae snapped his head back. Surprisingly, Lee Sa-young looked uneasy.
What did he mean, "know"? That there was another Lee Sa-young inside him? Or was there something else he had been hiding? Cha Eui-jae was just as confused, but he couldn't miss this opportunity.
Cha Eui-jae nodded. It was time to pull out the old skills from his part-time job at the hangover soup restaurant.
"Yeah."
Feign ignorance and agree. Most people spilled their secrets after being nudged a little. Lee Sa-young narrowed his eyes briefly before lowering his lashes, deep in thought.
"...Where did you hear it? You don't even have a phone..."
Cha Eui-jae folded his arms and stared intently at Lee Sa-young. Lee Sa-young, busy thinking, let out a short sigh.
"Oh..."
He ruffled his hair in frustration.
"Damn it. You saw it on the Hunter channel, didn't you?"
Normally, this guy wouldn't have given away any clues, but now he was just spilling everything on his own. Must be disoriented. Good thing I hit him on the head, thought Cha Eui-jae, letting out a scoff loud enough for him to hear. He hadn't opened the Hunter channel in a while, so he scrolled through the backlog of messages.
And what greeted him was...
.
.
.
[5] Gyu-Gyu: J, come to chat~
[5] Gyu-Gyu: If you don't show up, I'm gonna assume you two are dating for real~
[8] I Am An Artisan: Do we even need more words?
[8] I Am An Artisan: You saw the picture too.
[8] I Am An Artisan: He was carrying them like they were a sacred treasure.
[29] Marble Seller Boy: Uh, what's going on again?
[8] I Am An Artisan: Another latecomer.
[8] I Am An Artisan: Hurry up and read the article.
[8] I Am An Artisan: J and 240 are dating, it says.
What?
[11] Shield Guy: Ugh...
[11] Shield Guy: We don't know anything either.
[11] Shield Guy: The guild's phone line has been cut off.
[11] Shield Guy: Don't contact us.
[11] Shield Guy: I'm going into a dungeon too.
[6] Honeybee: Hey, aren't you gonna give a straight answer?
[6] Honeybee: What's the deal with those two, seriously?
[6] Honeybee: Are they dating?
[6] Honeybee: Or are they scheming something together?
[11] Shield Guy: Shield Guy is currently unavailable.
[6] Honeybee: "Currently unavailable"? Are you kidding me?
[6] Honeybee: Hey, Seo Min-gi, come out!
[34] A Small Miracle Seo Min-gi: A Small Miracle Seo Min-gi is currently unavailable.
[8] I Am An Artisan: This sneaky behavior is wild.
[6] Honeybee: Huh.
[5] Gyu-Gyu: Hahahahahaha.
[6] Honeybee: Why don't you all just say you're dating too?
[11] Shield Guy: Please refrain from saying "dating." I have PTSD from that.
[6] Honeybee: Ugh.
Cha Eui-jae grabbed Lee Sa-young by the collar as he fumbled around his throat. His eyes glowed bright blue.
"What did you do?"

chapters.title: Chapter 176: Wavelength
chapters.content:
Chapter 176: Wavelength
"What did you do?"
"...What?"
"I said, what did you do!"
Despite having his collar grabbed, Lee Sa-young just blinked with a blank expression, showing no resistance. He still didn't seem fully conscious.
But Cha Eui-jae wasn't in his right mind either. He couldn't even calm his pounding heart, still reeling from Lee Sa-young's shocking statement, only to now be faced with this unbelievable reality. The dating rumors, which had seemed like nothing more than idle chatter, had exploded to the point of even being discussed in the Hunter channel!
'What the hell did those Mackerels do?'
They said one call would clear things up, but it seems like that was all empty words. Cha Eui-jae ground his teeth.
'It would've been better if the rumors were about us being enemies or rivals.'
Cha Eui-jae, in an attempt to snap Lee Sa-young back to his senses, shook the collar he was gripping. Lee Sa-young's head bobbed weakly. Soon, Lee Sa-young winced and grabbed his head.
"Hyung..."
"Speak clearly."
"It hurts..."
Cha Eui-jae loosened his grip on Lee Sa-young's collar. Or rather, his strength just gave out. A groan escaped from Lee Sa-young's lips.
Had it been so long since he'd hit someone that he lost control of his strength? Even if he's an S-grade, could it still hurt? It must, right? While Cha Eui-jae was lost in thought, Lee Sa-young slowly lifted his body, then promptly buried his face into Cha Eui-jae's shoulder.
The soft hair brushing against him woke Cha Eui-jae up. He quickly grabbed the arm that was wrapped around his waist like a snake.
"You're trying to get away with this by being cute again, aren't you?"
"...Huh?"
Lee Sa-young, who had been burying his face in Cha Eui-jae's shoulder, lifted his head. With his cheek resting on Cha Eui-jae's shoulder, Lee Sa-young gazed up at him with a sulky expression.
"It really hurts..."
"..."
Is he acting right now, or is he really hurt? Cha Eui-jae was still feeling uneasy. He glanced at Lee Sa-young's pale, slender neck and saw red marks where his hand had been. Cha Eui-jae scratched his head. Sharing a body like this was more uncomfortable than he expected.
"Does your neck hurt?"
"Yes, and my head."
A small cough escaped. Cha Eui-jae, now awkward, muttered while staring off into space.
"...I kind of choked you."
"Oh..."
Lee Sa-young let out a soft sigh, squinting his eyes. His black fingers grazed the red marks on his neck. Now that his senses had returned, his eyes glinted with interest, the dullness gone. His lips curled into a smile.
"So, that's your thing, huh?"
"No, it's not!"
Cha Eui-jae shouted abruptly. Lee Sa-young, still rubbing his neck, murmured.
"Choking people is kind of...a bad habit, don't you think?"
"When I woke up, there wasn't you but some other guy standing there, so what was I supposed to do?"
"Oh... And you choked without saying a word? That's pretty violent..."
"That guy was saying weird things."
"What weird things?"
"..."
Cha Eui-jae clammed up. He didn't want to repeat the vile words that had been spoken. Lee Sa-young squirmed against his waist, nudging him to speak. When Cha Eui-jae looked down, Lee Sa-young's expression was surprisingly calm, despite being possessed and attacked.
Well, it was probably better to explain everything now rather than letting things spiral out of control. Cha Eui-jae mumbled and began to speak.
"He suggested that we sleep together..."
"Huh?"
Lee Sa-young frowned. Cha Eui-jae hurriedly clarified.
"Just to sleep! Literally sleep! Nothing weird!"
"I wasn't going to misunderstand, but now it seems like you're the one who had weird thoughts, Hyung."
"Shut up."
When Cha Eui-jae clenched his fist and shook it, Lee Sa-young smiled and made an X over his mouth with his fingers. He raised his eyebrows.
"I get it, keep talking. What happened next?"
"Then he asked me to choke him more... I mean, is that guy crazy? Why would he want to be choked more?"
"Oh... So you choked him again? Is that why my neck is like this?"
"Are you nuts? I let go right away."
"Sigh..."
Lee Sa-young sighed deeply, blinking slowly as if exhausted.
"And then, what else?"
"And then..."
Cha Eui-jae remembered the face that kept smiling as he choked him.
According to Hong Ye-seong, their 'fundamentals' were the same. By 'fundamentals of the soul,' it must mean the core nature of a person. Even if they lived completely different lives, if their core didn't change, they would be the same being.
But...
"..."
"Hyung?"
"But it just felt..."
But the Lee Sa-young he had just faced gave him an odd feeling of discomfort. Not because of the absurd suggestion to sleep together or the perverse request to be choked. If someone asked him where the discomfort stemmed from...
From everything that made up Lee Sa-young.
In fact, there had been a strange sense of unease from the very first moment he saw him. His eyes, like empty glass beads, reflected nothing but Cha Eui-jae.
They say eyes are the windows to the soul. But in the eyes of that Lee Sa-young, there was no soul or self. They only reflected what was in front of them, like a mirror.
And even the energy he gave off felt strange. More like a dungeon than a human...
"..."
"It just felt... off."
Cha Eui-jae finished his sentence uncomfortably. Lee Sa-young lowered his gaze, deep in thought, and licked his lips. As Cha Eui-jae watched Lee Sa-young's black tongue slide across his red lips, a sharp glare returned to his face.
He had almost let himself get sidetracked again. This guy knew exactly how to distract people with his looks and touches before sliding into a different conversation like a snake.
Cha Eui-jae grabbed both of Lee Sa-young's cheeks with his hands. Lee Sa-young's eyes widened as he looked up at him.
"Anyway, what did you do?"
"Weren't you already aware of this?"
"Say it yourself. Before I storm over to the fish market."
"What... I didn't do much."
Didn't do much? No way the Hunter channel would be blowing up over nothing. When Cha Eui-jae shot a glare, Lee Sa-young smirked.
"I just did what you did, Hyung."
"What I did?"
"When I saw you asleep, I picked you up and carried you home."
Lee Sa-young tilted his head slightly, blinking. His eyelashes fluttered.
"Is that a crime? I just did what you did, Hyung."
Carried him? Cha Eui-jae's mind flashed to an image associated with that word. A hazy, low-resolution image formed in his head. The photo of J carrying Lee Sa-young. At that time, J had cradled Lee Sa-young like a princess...
'Fuck.'
Chills ran down Cha Eui-jae's spine. He jumped up from his seat and began rummaging through the room. Lee Sa-young sat on the floor, propping his chin on one knee.
"What are you looking for?"
"Where's my phone?"
"I have it."
Lee Sa-young pulled Cha Eui-jae's phone out of his pocket and handed it over. Cha Eui-jae snatched the phone and quickly turned it on, connecting to the internet. The headline on the portal site's main page looked ominous.
[What's the relationship between Lee Sa-young and J? The Pado Guild remains silent...]
With trembling hands, Cha Eui-jae clicked on the article. As the loading icon spun for several seconds, Cha Eui-jae's anxiety grew.
Tap, tap, tap. He nervously tapped the floor with his foot. As soon as the article finished loading, Cha Eui-jae found himself staring into Lee Sa-young's eyes. Not the real Lee Sa-young in front of him, but the one in the photo.
The Lee Sa-young in the picture was smiling as if he had seen it all...
"..."
And the masked man held him quietly in his arms.
As Cha Eui-jae froze, Lee Sa-young stood up lightly and walked behind him. Then he pressed his lips to the nape of Cha Eui-jae's neck, exposed beneath his soft gray hair. Cha Eui-jae's body tensed in response.
At the same time, a delayed message notification popped up over the photo on the screen.
The sender was;
Ha-eun: Uncle, Grandma's asking if this is true
The body in Cha Eui-jae's arms trembled. Lee Sa-young pressed his lips to the end of Cha Eui-jae's hair once more.
"They say you can't even drink water carelessly in front of kids."
***
Cha Eui-jae didn't get angry, surprisingly. No, perhaps it was more accurate to say that he didn't have the energy to be angry. He simply stood there trembling with his phone in hand for a while, then suddenly pushed Lee Sa-young away, who had been kissing the back of his neck. Stumbling slightly, he walked toward the bathroom.
Bang!
The door slammed shut.
Click.
He locked it.
Every action flowed as naturally as water. Lee Sa-young didn't tell him to open the door or knock on it. Instead, he pulled over a chair where he could see the bathroom door, sat down, and waited quietly.
It was kind of cute... If he wanted to isolate himself, he could've chosen the bedroom, but hiding in a corner like the bathroom? That was so typical of Cha Eui-jae.
Cha Eui-jae didn't come out for a full hour, and aside from the occasional heavy sigh or muffled scream, there was little sound from inside.
Lee Sa-young, who was now sitting backward on the chair with his arms resting on the backrest and his chin propped on top, rolled his eyes. Once separated from Cha Eui-jae, the unwelcome guest within him began to stir again. His consciousness, which had been focused on Cha Eui-jae, slowly drifted toward the intruder. Cha Eui-jae's voice echoed in his mind.
"Then he asked me to choke him more... I mean, is that guy crazy? Why would he want to be choked more?"
Lee Sa-young let out a short sigh.
'Why, you ask...'
He knew why the intruder had acted that way. Resting his cheek on his arm, Lee Sa-young relaxed his body.
Could someone who wandered alone in a world on the verge of destruction for a very long time still be normal?
'No way...'
Like a large rock eroded by water and wind, both the body and mind would have gradually worn away. Once everything had been worn down, even the emotions that once consumed him would've eroded as well.
Sorrow, anger, regret— all of it would've vanished. And in their place, he would've spent each day ruminating on nothing but his purpose.
Only obsession would remain.
'Am I right?'
The intruder didn't respond. But Lee Sa-young knew he was right. He could feel the other version of himself writhing in discomfort.
How would someone who had lost everything, including their own body, react upon having a living body again? They would surely be excited by stimuli that once felt familiar but now seemed foreign. Especially if the one providing those stimuli was Cha Eui-jae...
Lee Sa-young touched his still throbbing neck. He didn't need to check to know that there was probably a bruise. Closing his eyes, he listened to the sound of water running— Cha Eui-jae must have turned on the faucet.
Was there anything that made one feel more alive than the stimuli that Cha Eui-jae provided?
'If it were me, I would've asked for more too...'
Lee Sa-young understood the other Lee Sa-young's feelings. And it deeply disturbed him.

chapters.title: Chapter 177: Wavelength
chapters.content:
Chapter 177: Wavelength
It took Cha Eui-jae an hour and a half more to finally open the locked door. During that time, Lee Sa-young waited patiently. In fact, it wasn't even about patience. Compared to the time he'd already spent waiting, this was just a fleeting moment.
Hearing footsteps approaching the door, Lee Sa-young lifted his head. Cha Eui-jae, sticking just his head out of the door, squinted at him.
"...What are you doing there?"
"I waited for you... until you came out."
Lee Sa-young, with his cheek resting on his arm draped over the back of a chair, narrowed his eyes and smiled.
"Have you calmed down a bit?"
Still hiding behind the door, Cha Eui-jae glared at Lee Sa-young.
"This is all Mackerel's move, isn't it?"
"Well, I suppose it is."
"I saw the pictures. It was almost like you threatened them to take good shots. Wasn't that your doing?"
"Ah, so even you think the photos came out well. That's a relief..."
"You little... Those guys are not going to get away with this."
Cha Eui-jae, spitting out curses, strode over. His expression was far from calm, as if he was ready to march into a fish market and thrash some mackerels. Lee Sa-young, deliberately tilted his head to show off the handprint still visible on his neck. Cha Eui-jae's menacing aura softened a bit at the sight.
"But thanks to the article, all the other issues were swept under the rug."
Lee Sa-young thought that it would be nice if the bruise lasted longer. Maybe when it started to fade, he could ask for another one. His lips curled into a smile at the sudden thought. He reached out and grabbed Cha Eui-jae's coat hem as he approached.
"I think we used our names to quell any anxiety."
"..."
"Does that make you feel a little better?"
But Cha Eui-jae, without answering, kept his mouth shut. There was a strange shadow over his face that Lee Sa-young didn't like.
Lee Sa-young studied his expression, trying to read his thoughts. This topic needs to be dropped, he decided, smoothly changing the subject.
"Aren't you hungry? You've been sleeping for quite a while."
"Ah, a little."
"Let's go downstairs and eat. I'll have them bring food to the guild leader's office."
"Do we really have to? Can't we eat here?"
"Oh... do you want to eat here? In your shirts?"
Lee Sa-young smiled mischievously and slipped his fingers inside Cha Eui-jae's shirt. Cha Eui-jae grabbed Lee Sa-young's wrist and pulled it off.
"Hey, someone could see us. We'd have to take off the masks to eat."
"No one can just walk into the guild leader's office. Besides, I've got work piled up that I need to do."
"..."
"If you're that worried... Should I have someone stand watch at the door?"
"No, we don't need to go that far..."
Cha Eui-jae's expression turned reluctant. Whether Lee Sa-young was aware or not, seeing that face made him want to tease him even more. He got up from his chair and motioned toward the entrance with his chin. Cha Eui-jae, fiddling with the buttons of his loose shirt, muttered in response.
"Let me just change clothes first. Where are my clothes?"
"In the dressing room. Your mask's there, too."
Cha Eui-jae headed toward the dressing room as if it were his own house. It was a nice sight, seeing him navigate the room so naturally. The sound of rustling clothes followed as he undressed and dressed. Lee Sa-young crossed his arms, listening to the noises. After a brief sigh, Cha Eui-jae emerged, now completely transformed into J.
All it took was putting on a mask, but the atmosphere was completely different from the loose and relaxed Cha Eui-jae. The mask, which concealed not just his expression but his entire face, exuded an eerie pressure.
A little later, the two stepped into the elevator side by side. It had only been a few months since they last rode the elevator together, but it felt like ages ago. Back then, Cha Eui-jae had picked a corner to stand in, alert to everything around him. Now, he stood calmly next to Lee Sa-young.
Lee Sa-young, staring at Cha Eui-jae's light gray hair, asked,
"By the way, do your grandmother and Ha-eun know that you're J?"
"Hm? No."
Cha Eui-jae gave a brief answer.
"I told them I closed the hangover soup restaurant... and that I'd be working at the Pado Guild now. They only know I'm a hunter."
"But the text earlier... it seemed like they knew."
"...I don't think so?"
He tilted his head as if something didn't add up.
Cha Eui-jae hadn't told them he was J. Not when he first showed up to eat white broth soup at their house, nor when he later asked to work at their shop.
The elevator doors opened. As Lee Sa-young had mentioned, the floor where the guild leader's office was located was quiet.
Cha Eui-jae walked down the hallway, his footsteps echoing. Then suddenly, he came to an abrupt stop.
"Oh."
A long-forgotten memory seemed to have surfaced. Lee Sa-young, walking beside him, looked back in confusion.
"What is it?"
"I think... they might know. Yeah, I think they know."
Cha Eui-jae absentmindedly rubbed his mask, sweat beginning to form on his face under the mask. His voice, already distorted by the mask, trembled with unease.
"Now that I think about it... back then, I went there in my J outfit..."
"What do you mean?"
"The clothes I wore when I was J!"
Cha Eui-jae instinctively followed the scent the moment he opened his eyes, knocked on the door of the hangover soup restaurant, and entered. At that time, the TV in the shop was showing a documentary commemorating the 8th anniversary of the West Sea rift. A picture of J, wearing his battle gear, had even flashed on the screen. His grandmother had been chopping garlic while watching that, and Cha Eui-jae had been standing there in his J uniform, looking ragged.
'No, she might not have noticed...'
Cha Eui-jae quickly turned to Lee Sa-young.
"Hey, Lee Sa-young. Did you watch the J documentary? The one where Hunter Song Jo-heon gets interviewed."
"...Huh?"
"Did you see it or not? Tell me quickly."
"Hah."
Lee Sa-young looked at him for a moment before scoffing. A short laugh quickly turned into outright derision. Narrowing his eyes, Lee Sa-young responded.
"Of course, I saw it... Pado Guild made it."
"...What?"
"From planning to funding and support, Pado Guild handled the whole thing... So yeah, I saw it."
"Whaaat?"
"I swear... Next time, we should slap the guild logo on it, too."
Lee Sa-young muttered in disbelief. Was that so? Maybe the shock of eight years passing had wiped out all the trivial details from his memory. Cha Eui-jae quickly grabbed Lee Sa-young by the shoulders.
"That aside, I didn't watch the whole thing. Just the interview and a bit before it. Did it show me in action?"
"Hm? Of course, it did. It showed you fighting, your pre-entry interview... everything."
"..."
"Why do you ask?"
The uneasiness grew stronger.
Cha Eui-jae desperately tried to recall the past. What had his grandmother done back then?
He had finished his meal but had hesitated, unsure what to do since he didn't have money to pay. His grandmother hadn't scolded him but had instead handed him a navy jacket and a black hat.
"If you wander around in that state in daylight, you'll get caught. Wear it."
After that, he'd sheepishly swapped out his tattered jacket for the one she'd given him and pulled the hat down low. Why had she given him a jacket and a hat? Because of his wounds? No.
'Did she mean I'd get caught...?'
Cha Eui-jae paled.
Now that he thought about it, right after coming out of the West Sea rift, he hadn't been in his right mind. He hadn't realized that his clothes would make him easy to identify, or that he should cover his face. He had been focused on satisfying the most basic need— hunger.
If it hadn't been for his grandmother's kindness, he might've been caught right then and there. His bare face, and the fact that he had returned. Even his decision to run away.
Cha Eui-jae covered his mouth. His voice trembled uncontrollably.
"She must know... She was watching the documentary, and she even gave me a hat..."
"Well, that makes sense."
"What?"
"Seems like you don't realize how much footage of you was shown."
Lee Sa-young stared at Cha Eui-jae with an expressionless face, then turned away. His voice, oddly cold, followed.
"You were all over the TV back then. People debated all day whether they should send J in or not... When the decision was made to let you enter, they showed all your achievements, your last interview, your back as you entered the rift... They wrung every last bit out of it."
His tone was that of someone relaying secondhand information. Then again, Lee Sa-young had been in no condition to watch anything at that time. He had been in poor health, barely able to move. This was news even to him. Cha Eui-jae suddenly asked,
"Who told you this?"
"..."
Lee Sa-young quietly stared at Cha Eui-jae before shrugging.
"Jung Bin."
"..."
"I lived with him briefly... anyway."
Lee Sa-young crossed his arms and tapped them lightly with his fingers.
"You were more famous than you thought. There wasn't anyone who didn't know you."
"..."
"Well, after they set up a memorial stone thinking you were dead, people slowly forgot."
It was probably inevitable. As time passed, newer, more outstanding hunters would have appeared.
Like sand burying more sand, people cover old memories with new ones. They wouldn't have remembered a hunter who died trapped in some rift for long. At best, they might think, 'Ah, there was someone like that,' from time to time. They certainly wouldn't have believed he was still alive.
Even he had lost his way and wandered.
"I couldn't have just left it like that."
But.
"Who said they could just forget?"
Cha Eui-jae stared blankly at Lee Sa-young. Lee Sa-young, who had been staring straight ahead, turned his head.
"Still..."
Their eyes met.
"At least spending money on that documentary seems to have been worth it. If they were playing it even in such an out-of-the-way place."
Lee Sa-young smiled, lifting the corner of his mouth.
"Right?"

chapters.title: Chapter 178: Wavelength
chapters.content:
Chapter 178 - Wavelength
Thump.
'Huh?'
Thump, thump, thump. Suddenly, his heartbeat started pounding loudly. Strangely. Nothing had changed, but something felt off.
Cha Eui-jae rubbed his chest. Meanwhile, Lee Sa-young had already taken a step ahead. His languid voice mixed with a sweet scent lingered in the air. Under the bright hallway lights, only his black silhouette was in Cha Eui-jae's view.
"I was going to include an interview with the director, but she kept refusing..."
"..."
"Jung Bin also turned it down, probably because of the director's orders. So, I got a little annoyed."
"..."
"Oh, but Song Jo-heon was surprisingly easy. I guess it was because of image management... He agreed right away."
There was an oddly playful tone in every word he spoke. Pale skin peeking through black hair, a neck marked with bruises from handprints, his swaying coat, and the sharp profile of his nose and lips visible when he slightly turned his head— Lee Sa-young's violet eyes were focused entirely on Cha Eui-jae. The emotion in those eyes...
"...Hyung?"
"..."
"What's wrong?"
Cha Eui-jae found himself looking at Lee Sa-young anew. Had Lee Sa-young always had such broad shoulders? Was he always this tall? He was now a half-head taller than Cha Eui-jae, who was already not short. When Cha Eui-jae didn't follow and stood frozen, Lee Sa-young turned around to face him.
Oddly enough, there was no trace of the boy whose life Cha Eui-jae had once saved. In front of him stood a fully-grown man. Without thinking, Cha Eui-jae asked,
"Why did you make it?"
"Make what? Oh, the documentary?"
"Yeah."
Lee Sa-young blinked as if Cha Eui-jae had said something strange. His response was so matter-of-fact, like it was the most obvious thing.
"I told you. I made it because stupid people kept forgetting you."
"The dead are bound to be forgotten. With time, everything..."
"Who said anyone's dead... Ugh, why are you suddenly acting like this?"
"Anyway, it was known that I was dead. They even put up a memorial stone."
"Are you so hungry that it's making you lose your mind?"
Lee Sa-young snapped irritably. Uncrossing his arms, he pointed his finger at Cha Eui-jae's face. Beyond his hand, those piercing violet eyes stared directly at Cha Eui-jae.
"The one who grabbed my hand first was you, Cha Eui-jae."
Cha Eui-jae remembered the face he had encountered in the ruins. Barely clinging to life, with a faint heartbeat, a chest rising and falling weakly, lips moving silently. A quiet plea for salvation.
"Please save me."
Cha Eui-jae had reached out his hand. And,
"It's okay."
He had grabbed the withered, deformed hand, melted away by venom, without the slightest hesitation.
Cha Eui-jae blinked. The withered hand was nowhere to be seen. Instead, a large, strong hand was now pointing directly at him. Lee Sa-young spoke as if spitting out the words.
"You promised me you'd come back."
"..."
"I just kept my promise."
Cha Eui-jae slightly parted his lips. He thought it was such a selfish request. Back then, Cha Eui-jae had no certainty that he would even survive. He had only reached out to the one hand he could hold onto, just like a drowning person grabs at anything they can.
But that boy.
That Lee Sa-young.
Even now, after eight years, he had not let go of his hand.
Cha Eui-jae felt his throat close up, unable to speak. What was the basis of this unwavering faith? The source of this endless belief? Lee Sa-young sighed, pulling his hand away from Cha Eui-jae's face. He began fiddling with his own hair with his black fingers.
"Are you satisfied now?"
"..."
"If you get it, come on. We need to eat something. This isn't good..."
Lee Sa-young clicked his tongue and turned around. But Cha Eui-jae couldn't move. No, he couldn't make himself move.
"..."
It felt like the ground beneath his feet was melting away. His fingertips and toes tingled. His heart was beating faster and faster, to the point where it made him feel breathless. His head felt blank.
Cha Eui-jae could barely swallow. He breathed, blinked, swallowed— each natural action felt forced. Every sense in his body was acutely, intensely focused on one thing. On Lee Sa-young.
Lee Sa-young's movements, as he turned back around, appeared in slow motion.
He blinked. With each blink, his long eyelashes fluttered. His plump lips parted slightly. His chest rose and fell faintly. His eyebrows shifted a little, and his brow furrowed slightly. His head tilted slightly to the right, causing his hair to sway. That sweet scent filled the air. His black fingertips, resting against his cheek, trembled slightly.
Cha Eui-jae covered his mask with both hands. Even if he could block out his sight, he couldn't block his sense of smell or hearing.
"Hyung?"
Lee Sa-young's curious voice called out to him. Cha Eui-jae's fingers fidgeted against the mask. Damn it.
'Why is this happening all of a sudden?'
Cha Eui-jae exhaled a slightly labored breath. He felt like he was suffocating, despite not being underwater.
If he kept facing Lee Sa-young like this, he'd collapse soon. He had a sudden, sharp instinct that this couldn't go on. Without realizing it, he took a step back. Then he quickly scanned his surroundings. He spotted the emergency exit door next to the elevator they had come down from. The green emergency light blinked.
"...Hup."
Cha Eui-jae inhaled sharply. And then,
Tap, tap, tap!
He bolted toward the emergency exit. Lee Sa-young, who had been staring at him in disbelief, clenched his teeth and ran his hand through his hair.
"What the... What are you doing now?!"
Cha Eui-jae began to dash down the long staircase. Shortly after, he heard the sound of footsteps thudding down behind him. They were hot on his heels. He could see a glimpse of Lee Sa-young's coat flapping behind him. Lee Sa-young shouted,
"Why are you acting like this? Are you crazy?"
I feel like I'm going crazy if I don't! Why!
Cha Eui-jae gritted his teeth and began leaping down several steps at a time. Thud, thud, thud— his legs were holding up fine. But Lee Sa-young wasn't far behind either. Damn it. He thought he heard a curse from behind, and then the footsteps seemed to take on a rhythm. He must be jumping too. That's when Cha Eui-jae yelled,
"Don't follow me!"
"Tell me why you're acting like this! Have you lost it? Or do you suddenly feel guilty?"
"It's not that, so stop following me!"
"How would I know if you don't say anything?!"
"You don't say anything either!"
"Are you seriously having this conversation right now? What the hell are you doing?"
Lee Sa-young was fuming.
"If you've got something to get off your chest, at least do it somewhere quiet and in person! Does this make any sense, having this conversation while running down the stairs?!"
He had a point. Cha Eui-jae was about to respond but quickly looked down. And he froze. Someone was standing by the emergency exit door, mouth agape, watching them.
Judging by the uniform and name tag, it seemed to be a member of the Pado Guild. Ah, I didn't think of this. After all this yelling, of course someone was going to check it out!
Cha Eui-jae clenched his teeth and moved his feet even faster. Thud, thud, thud— he could hear Lee Sa-young letting out a frustrated sigh from behind him. The presence behind him felt even more dangerous.
"Are you going to stop? How far are you planning to run?"
All the way to hell!
"Stop now! Otherwise, how are we going to talk, damn it!"
But the more Lee Sa-young pressed, the more stubborn Cha Eui-jae became. He didn't stop. The lower he went, the more people he felt around him, and the more Pado Guild members came out to see what was happening.
They gasped in shock when they saw Cha Eui-jae in his black mask, and screamed in fear when they saw Lee Sa-young, full of fury, chasing after him.
5th floor, 4th floor, 3rd floor— they were getting closer to the lobby. Cha Eui-jae quickly recalled the layout of the Pado Guild building from his last visit. If he went out the main door, too many eyes would be on him. He'd need to hide somewhere, escape through the back, or break through a window. Good. Perfect plan.
2nd floor,
1st floor.
Screech! His boots slid on the smooth floor. Cha Eui-jae grabbed the emergency exit door handle. Clatter. It rattled in his hand; the door was locked.
He glanced up to assess the situation. Lee Sa-young didn't look tired at all, except for his messy hair. And it was the coldest expression Cha Eui-jae had ever seen on his face. His heart was pounding erratically. He couldn't tell if it was from running down dozens of flights of stairs or because of Lee Sa-young.
Cha Eui-jae roughly grabbed the door handle. Without hesitation, he kicked the door.
Boom—!!
Bright light poured in. Cha Eui-jae quickly scanned his surroundings. Thanks to the glass, the wide lobby of the Pado Guild was fully visible along with the outside view.
Beyond the main entrance, there was a crowd of people. In one corner of the lobby, there was a company café where several hunters from the Pado Guild were sitting. He recognized some of the faces. He even made eye contact with Bae Won-woo, who, in shock, spat out his coffee.
A menacing aura loomed from behind him. If he was caught, he'd die. Cha Eui-jae bolted forward. Lee Sa-young, who had followed him out, shouted urgently.
"Wait, Hyu...!"
Lee Sa-young briefly glanced around and swallowed the word "Hyung", realizing where they were. Instead, he called out a name he had once repeated many times, long ago.
"J!"
J glanced back, but only for a brief moment. He began running for his life again. Lee Sa-young took in the scene of the lobby and let out a bitter laugh.
"Ah... this is driving me crazy, seriously."
"Oh..."
Bae Won-woo let out a dazed sigh. He didn't even have any coffee left to spill.
At that moment, a black head suddenly popped out from Lee Sa-young's shadow. It was Seo Min-gi, wearing his usual sunglasses. He slowly pulled his upper body out and placed a paper bag on the ground. It had the logo of a nearby Korean restaurant on it. Seo Min-gi blinked, confused, as he looked around.
"Huh?"
"..."
"Guild Leader? Why are you in the lobby? Weren't you in your office?"
"...Immediately."
"Sorry?"
Lee Sa-young, now watching Cha Eui-jae's rapidly disappearing figure turn into a black dot in the distance, pointed at him.
"Chase him. Now!"

"Haah..."
A large hand with strong bones placed the phone down. A deep sigh escaped. Bae Won-woo clutched his head, letting out a groan. He felt like he had sighed this hopelessly not long ago.
First floor of the Pado Guild building, the in-house café. Just a moment ago, the café had been bustling, but now it was quiet. Only three people sat there, lonely in the emptiness.
Bae Won-woo let out another deep sigh, as if the earth itself would collapse.
"Haah..."
"Stop sighing already, Vice-Guild Leader."
"...They saw everything, right?"
"Well, we tried to block it... but they probably saw the important parts."
A fresh scent of grass filled the air. The windows that once gave a clear view outside were now covered with vibrant greenery and flowers. Leaves fluttered gently. Kang Ji-soo stirred her strawberry latte with a straw. Her dark green eyes gleamed with a brilliant emerald hue. The café counter was now manned not by a part-time worker but by a vine-like human figure.
Bae Won-woo muttered.
"I should've just gone straight into the dungeon... Why did I bother getting coffee..."
"What's the point of regretting what's already done, Vice-Guild Leader? You should be thinking about how to fix it."
"What on earth is this, Sa-young? How many times are you planning to make the front page of the newspaper?"
"This time it's not my fault..."
A low, displeased voice responded. Lee Sa-young had his legs crossed, massaging his temple with his eyes closed.
The long dial tone stopped, and soon a notification announced that the call could not be connected. His delicate brow furrowed slightly. Lee Sa-young dialed again, his cold voice muttering.
"Now he's not even picking up..."
Bae Won-woo cautiously spoke.
"J... and, uh... they must've had a reason for playing 'catch me if you can,' right?"
"I don't know..."
A grinding sound came from his clenched teeth. An ominous aura flickered behind Lee Sa-young, who was dressed in a pitch-black coat. He spat out his words bitterly.
"Damn it. I asked them to eat, and they bolted like their feet were on fire. How is that my fault?"
"..."
"Tell me, Bae Won-woo. Is it my fault for asking someone who slept all day to grab a meal?"
"N-no... Asking someone to eat is a nice thing to do..."
"No matter what I said, they didn't respond. What, do they not want to eat with me? Not even talk to me? Run away like that?"
His voice grew more and more heated the longer he talked. This was dangerous. If things kept going like this, he might explode.
Kang Ji-soo and Bae Won-woo exchanged glances. You talk to him first. No? The Vice-Guild Leader should talk first. After silently debating for a while, Kang Ji-soo widened her eyes, daring him. Finally, Bae Won-woo broke the silence.
"Sa-young. Maybe... did you, um, did you imprison J?"
"What? Ha..."
Lee Sa-young scoffed. A fierce smile appeared on his delicate face.
"Are you blind? Does J look like someone who could be imprisoned?"
"That's not it, but... there's always the possibility of 'what if' in the world, right?"
"No."
Lee Sa-young answered firmly, and Bae Won-woo sighed in relief. He sneaked a glance at the back of his neck. A dark bruise, shaped like a handprint, stood out clearly. The body of an S-grade is tough— strong enough that only a great force could leave even a scratch. To leave such a clear mark on a body that resilient...
Ah, he didn't want to know anymore. Lee Sa-young was someone he had raised, cared for, and nurtured, through thick and thin. He didn't want to know about his rough romantic entanglements. But the signs were all too obvious, even to someone as clueless as Bae Won-woo. Everything pointed to one conclusion.
He covered his face in despair. If only he were a bit more oblivious!
At that moment, Kang Ji-soo slammed her glass down with a sharp sound.
"For now!"
Bae Won-woo and Lee Sa-young both looked up at the same time. Despite their sharp gazes, she clapped her hands without showing a hint of fear.
"Seo Min-gi said they followed J, right?"
A Small Miracle Seo Min-gi that emerged from Lee Sa-young's shadow, had immediately merged back into the shadows after receiving orders, without even grasping the situation. Bae Won-woo nodded.
"Y-yeah, that's right."
"Seo Min-gi won't be able to defeat J, but they should've at least secured their location, right? Probably turned on GPS too."
"That makes sense."
"If we just sit here talking amongst ourselves, we won't get any answers."
She raised her index finger sharply.
"Vice-Guild Leader, call Choi Go-yo."
"Huh? Got it."
"And Guild Leader..."
Kang Ji-soo added seriously.
"Try looking pitiful."
***
"Ha..."
Cha Eui-jae leaned on the building's railing, gazing up at the sky filled with swirling white ash. The ash fell like snow, indifferent to his feelings. He clicked his tongue in frustration. His phone vibrated incessantly in his hand. Running away had been a good idea, sure. But...
There was nowhere to go.
'How can there be nowhere to go...'
Cha Eui-jae rested his chin on his arm. The hangover soup restaurant was too obvious, Jung Bin was probably busy, and Hong Ye-seong's cozy love nest... Cha Eui-jae shook his head, pushing the thought aside. Too much hassle. Going to Hong Ye-seong to avoid Lee Sa-young would be like jumping from one hell to another.
'Maybe I should buy a house?'
He remembered that Han Seok-jeong was managing his old place. Maybe he should go there... Cha Eui-jae let out a small sigh.
"Sir, please return my phone. I'm begging you, this is life or death for me."
Seo Min-gi, tied to the rooftop railing by his wrist with a necktie, pleaded. The knot was loose enough to untie easily, but what truly bound him was not the necktie— it was Cha Eui-jae.
The phone buzzed again. Cha Eui-jae glanced at the caller ID. Guild Leader. Since he hadn't answered, it seemed the leader had shifted focus to Seo Min-gi. Cha Eui-jae crouched in front of him, showing him the phone screen.
"Answer and tell them you lost me."
"Uh? But..."
Crack, Cha Eui-jae silently cracked his knuckles. Seo Min-gi nodded quickly. The guild leader was far away, but Cha Eui-jae's fists were right here. Cha Eui-jae slid the call to answer and held the phone up to Seo Min-gi's ear. Seo Min-gi steadied his breath and spoke.
"Yes, Guild Leader."
—...
"Guild Leader?"
The phone was silent for a long moment before a soft intake of breath came through.
—J is there with you, isn't he?
"W-what? No, no, not at all!"
Seo Min-gi's voice cracked and squeaked as his attempt at lying fell apart miserably. Cha Eui-jae grabbed Seo Min-gi by the collar and mouthed the words;
"Do you want to die?"
Seo Min-gi frantically shook his head. His sunglasses rattled against the phone screen. Meanwhile, Lee Sa-young remained silent. Finally, his voice, now subdued, asked quietly.
—Did I do something wrong?
"..."
Seo Min-gi's jaw dropped. Cha Eui-jae, holding the phone, was equally stunned. He had never heard that tone from him before. Lee Sa-young continued to mutter.
—I just wanted to have a meal with you, but you ran off like that...
...Is that so?
Come to think of it, Lee Sa-young must have been taken aback too. They had been talking normally, and he suddenly bolted. But still...
Cha Eui-jae rubbed the back of his neck. Hearing his voice made the hair on the back of his neck stand on end. His ears itched, and his fingers curled involuntarily.
'If just his voice is doing this, how could I possibly face him in person!'
—...Hyung, are you angry? Are you really not going to answer me?
Cha Eui-jae opened his mouth but then stopped, holding his breath. He felt like his voice would come out weird if he spoke now. Meanwhile, Seo Min-gi, sensing Cha Eui-jae's mood, untied the necktie around his wrist. He slowly scooted away, inching further from the phone.
Just as Cha Eui-jae was about to say something, Lee Sa-young spoke first.
—Then I'll...
Something appeared behind him. It was a sensation he'd felt a few times before. Cha Eui-jae immediately turned around. A large door had appeared in the middle of the rooftop. Slowly, the door creaked open. On the other side was a space filled with greenery, like a botanical garden. The scent of fresh grass wafted in.
"Eek."
Romantic Opener, clinging to the doorknob, let out a faint squeak as he fainted. Long legs gracefully stepped over Romantic Opener's limp body and touched down on the rooftop floor. A black coat fluttered. Cha Eui-jae muttered silently.
Shit.
"...I do have some sense."
Shit!

chapters.title: Chapter 180: Wavelength
chapters.content:
Chapter 180 - Wavelength
Lee Sa-young, still holding the phone to his ear, stared directly at Cha Eui-jae. He then made a point of ending the call and tilted his head slightly. As soon as Cha Eui-jae heard the beep, he shot to his feet and stumbled backward, hitting the railing with his waist.
Should I just jump? He glanced downward. From this height, he figured he'd be fine even if he fell. But Lee Sa-young immediately reacted.
"Where are you looking? Turn your eyes back here."
"..."
"Look at me."
Smart bastard. Cha Eui-jae held onto the railing, determined. If push came to shove, he really would jump. Lee Sa-young smiled, but there wasn't even a hint of laughter in his eyes.
"Oh... are you going to fall?"
"..."
"Should I fall with you? This time, instead of the stairs, maybe we should run down the main road, side by side. That would make for an even better rumor, don't you think?"
Who do you think is responsible for this? You don't even understand how I feel. Cha Eui-jae, on the verge of snapping and saying, "Fine, let's both die then!" was interrupted by a dull voice from behind Lee Sa-young.
"Guild Leader, don't you know what it means to be pitiful? You're supposed to act pitiful, not pick a fight."
Beyond the black coat, a red head popped out from the door. It was Kang Ji-soo, whom Cha Eui-jae had glimpsed earlier in the lobby. Next to her was Bae Won-woo, scratching his head with a grimace. Lee Sa-young shrugged.
"Oh... I've never really been pitiful before, so I wouldn't know. My bad?"
Instead of answering, Cha Eui-jae turned his head slightly, enough so only Lee Sa-young's black coat remained in his sight. He heard a faint chuckle from Lee Sa-young. In his place, what entered Cha Eui-jae's vision was Seo Min-gi, crawling toward the door on all fours.
"..."
"..."
Sensing eyes on him, Seo Min-gi glanced back, nodded solemnly, and bowed his head.
"This seems to be a matter that you and the Guild Leader need to resolve personally, sir."
Then he resumed crawling. Resolve it? How? I'm not even in the right state of mind! But before Cha Eui-jae could say anything, Seo Min-gi had reached the door.
He grabbed the doorknob, scooped up the collapsed Romantic Opener, and said,
"Good luck!"
"I hope you have a meaningful conversation."
Then, he shut the door behind him.
BAM!
The sound of the door slamming was like the fall of a guillotine. Soon after, the door vanished, as if it had never existed, dissolving into dust. Only the two of them remained on the rooftop. Cha Eui-jae deliberately turned his head away. White ash gently fell, soft as snow.
A short breath escaped him. Lee Sa-young ran a hand through his hair, the soft curls scattering.
Cha Eui-jae suddenly noticed that Lee Sa-young was holding a square shopping bag in his left hand, with a logo from a Korean set-menu restaurant. Seeing it made something in his chest churn strangely. Lee Sa-young's voice, low and calm, asked,
"Do you hate seeing me?"
No.
"Then why did you run away?"
...
"Did I do something wrong?"
It was the same question as earlier, but the atmosphere and the tone were different. Cha Eui-jae found it oddly amusing that the accusatory tone suited Lee Sa-young so well. That bold confidence, almost enough to irritate, suited him. Slowly, Cha Eui-jae turned his head. He opened his mouth slightly.
The expression on Lee Sa-young's face in front of him was...
"If I did something wrong, you should tell me what it was. You usually talk just fine, but suddenly, you're keeping your mouth shut. What's going on?"
It was an expression he had never seen before.
"Answer me, Cha Eui-jae."
Lee Sa-young's delicate face gradually twisted. His violet eyes blazed with intensity, but the corners of his eyes reddened, as if he were about to cry.
Cha Eui-jae's mind went blank. His grip tightened on the railing. With a loud creak, the iron rail twisted under the pressure. Lee Sa-young spoke again, clearly and deliberately, enunciating each word.
"I can't know everything. If you don't tell me, I won't know."
"..."
"Guessing and assuming only goes so far. How long do you expect me to wait?"
His breath caught in his throat. His once-empty mind was now flooded with tangled thoughts. What should I say?
"Thanks for waiting"?
No, that's too cliché. And would that be appropriate to say to someone on the verge of tears? Should I apologize? But I already did. Can I repeat what I've already said?
Whenever Cha Eui-jae stood before Lee Sa-young, he always ended up overthinking. But even then, Cha Eui-jae always acted faster than he spoke. He reached out and grabbed Lee Sa-young's arm. The firm muscle he felt through the leather jacket was strangely reassuring.
Expressing his true feelings was difficult. He hadn't always been the most open about everything, but at some point, it became especially hard. There came a time when his words seemed unnecessary. Since the day every word he said carried more weight than he wanted, he had resorted to action instead. He had to, in order to save more people...
"It's not your fault, it's just that I..."
Cha Eui-jae swallowed hard. His throat felt swollen, and even swallowing was difficult. He stammered, continuing with effort.
"It's just... you..."
Thump, thump, thump— his heart was pounding out of control. It was always like this when he was in front of Lee Sa-young. A large hand covered his own, offering him warmth and comfort. Cha Eui-jae gripped Lee Sa-young's coat, crumpling it slightly.
"The fact that you waited for me..."
That was just...
Gulp, he swallowed again.
What does someone who's lost need the most? What does someone who can't even trust themselves need? From the moment Cha Eui-jae entered the West Sea rift, he had been like a kite with its string cut, a ship adrift on a vast sea.
He had wandered for what felt like an eternity.
"..."
Until one day, for reasons unknown, he had suddenly been flung back out of the West Sea rift. After so long. Cha Eui-jae suddenly stopped breathing and blinked. Fragments of memories flashed before him.
Thunk! A sharp blade pierced through the skull, crushing the windpipe with brutal force. Cha Eui-jae bent over, gripping the sword's hilt tightly, gasping for breath. Huff, huff, huff...
It didn't take long for his ragged breathing to slow.
Even though he had killed the last remaining monster, the rift's gate did not open.
Instead,
Silence descended.
There was no sound of wind blowing, no rustling of grass, not even the chirping of insects. This world was eerily quiet. He could clearly hear the sound of his heart pounding— thump, thump, thump. It was the only noise. The more he listened to it, the more anxious he became. How ridiculous, to grow nervous from hearing his own heartbeat.
Cha Eui-jae looked up at the sky. The white sky was still raining down ash. Despite killing the last monster, nothing had changed. No— one thing had changed.
He was now completely alone.
His dry lips parted.
"Why..."
He blinked heavily, struggling.
"Why won't it open?"
Cha Eui-jae released his grip from the sword hilt. His hands, which had turned pale from squeezing too hard, slowly regained their color. A sign that he was still alive. He glanced around.
White and red things.
Things that had stopped.
Things that were dead.
I'm the only one alive in this world.
The moment he realized that, what hit him was—
"I want to go back."
Cold sweat dripped down. He felt like throwing up. Cha Eui-jae lifted his head. The blinding white sky was painfully bright. It was unbearable, so he squinted his eyes. Soon, a single tear trailed down his dry cheek.
"I want to live..."
It was an unbearable loneliness.
A sharp pain snapped him back to his senses. He glanced down to see black fingers scratching the back of his hand. A thin, long, red scratch remained on the back of his hand. Cha Eui-jae looked up. Lee Sa-young was staring at him, his face still twisted as if on the verge of crying.
Their eyes met. Cha Eui-jae's heart, which had been pounding in anxiety, seemed to slow for a moment, only to start racing even faster.
The reason Cha Eui-jae had managed to find his way after being dropped into an unfamiliar place, the reason he hadn't lost his path despite being like a kite with its string cut, floundering in the wind—
The hand that covered his own gently rubbed his fingers, as if urging him. There had been days when even such small warmth felt desperately needed.
After the rift, my life felt like it was built on you. And that's why...
"I was happy."
"..."
"So don't cry..."
As he spoke those heavy words, he felt lighter, as if a shackle had been lifted. Haah, Cha Eui-jae exhaled softly and rested his forehead on Lee Sa-young's shoulder.
Thunk, the shopping bag fell to the ground.
As if waiting for the moment, a large hand wrapped around the back of his neck. The fingers massaged his nape gently, as if praising him. The other hand circled around his waist, naturally. His shoulder twitched. Cha Eui-jae gasped, goosebumps rising as heat rushed to his head in an instant. Ah, wait.
'This isn't right.'
This shouldn't be happening, but his mind was too jumbled to think clearly, perhaps because of the heat. Instincts urging him to be closer conflicted with reason telling him this was wrong. His hand twitched. His whole body was burning up. Just then, something wet touched his earlobe.
"You do need a different kind of advice..."
A stinging pain shot through his ear.
"Hey, what are you doing...!"
Cha Eui-jae tried to pull his neck away, but the hand gripping the back of his neck kept him from moving. It felt like he was trapped in a fiery prison called Lee Sa-young. A low chuckle echoed near him. Lick, a tongue swept across his ear. Cha Eui-jae barely stifled a scream.
"How was it?"
"W-what?"
"My performance."
"What?"
Cha Eui-jae's eyes shot wide open as he jerked his body back. It was surprisingly easy to lean away. Only then did Lee Sa-young's face come into view. The tear-stained, twisted expression was gone, replaced with a sly smirk tugging at his lips. The redness around his eyes had disappeared as well.
Lee Sa-young stuck out his black tongue.
"Gotcha."
Ah, damn it.
Cha Eui-jae clenched his teeth and pushed the body wrapped around him away.
"Screw off!"
"Why so upset, Hyung?"
The arm that had loosened around his waist quickly tightened again. A firm thigh pressed between his legs. With natural ease, Lee Sa-young lifted Cha Eui-jae slightly, pressing his lips to the jawline of his mask.
"After such a fiery confession."

chapters.title: Chapter 181: Wavelength
chapters.content:
Chapter 181 - Wavelength
With just the strength of his thighs, his body was lifted high into the air. The feet that had been firmly planted on the ground were now hovering. He was used to looking down at people, but never quite like this. Surprised, Cha Eui-jae pressed his hand over Lee Sa-young's face, trying to push it away.
"A confession? What are you talking about? Hey! Are you crazy? get off me!"
However,
As if waiting for it, something wet licked between his palm and fingers. Through the gaps of his parted fingers, he caught a glimpse of violet eyes. Thinly curved, as if laughing in amusement. His fingertips instinctively recoiled. A strange tickling sensation fluttered around his heart.
"Don't just call me 'hey.'"
"Move your tongue!"
"You're the one who put your hand on my face first."
"You shoved your face in first. Let me go, now."
"If you don't move your hand like this..."
Lee Sa-young tilted his head slightly and began to lightly bite the tip of Cha Eui-jae's thumb. Damn it. Cha Eui-jae squeezed his eyes shut and quickly withdrew his hand. A low chuckle escaped. Every time he heard that laughter, his whole body tingled. It was fortunate he was wearing a mask. He couldn't even imagine how his bare face might look right now.
Cha Eui-jae scolded sharply, for no reason.
"You go through all this acting just to hear me say something..."
But he couldn't finish his sentence. Even if the teary eyes were an act, the sight of Lee Sa-young pierced through Cha Eui-jae's heart like an arrow.
"Guessing and assuming only goes so far. How long do you expect me to wait?"
Unintentionally or not, it was true that he'd kept Lee Sa-young waiting. The sharp energy quickly disappeared, replaced by softer, more subdued words.
"...saying something like that."
"It's only because I have to go this far just to make you speak."
Lee Sa-young's reply came in a casual tone. He moved forward a few steps, still holding Cha Eui-jae slightly aloft. Cha Eui-jae's hips bumped into a cold railing. Trying to avoid the overwhelming gaze, he leaned back a little, and the distance beneath him opened up. A cold breeze brushed against his cheek. His ash-gray hair fluttered.
"It's hard to get you to answer, and even harder to hear what you're really thinking."
Without Lee Sa-young's arms holding him, it felt as though he might fall at any moment.
"You're used to enduring right up to your limit, for no reason..."
The hand gripping his waist tickled his side.
"To get someone so tight-lipped to talk... it takes at least a few tears."
"...I don't need that."
Cha Eui-jae barely managed to get the words out. Lee Sa-young bent forward. Their bodies pressed against each other. Lee Sa-young rested his cheek against Cha Eui-jae's chest, looking up at him. The wind tousled his dark hair.
"Were you happy?"
"..."
Instead of answering, Cha Eui-jae squeezed his eyes shut, desperately wishing for his heart to stop. He was sure Lee Sa-young could hear every loud thump of his heartbeat.
"Come on, answer."
"..."
"So that I know... it was worth waiting."
Each time Cha Eui-jae breathed, his chest subtly rose and fell, and Lee Sa-young could feel it all. It was so unfair. He was collecting undeniable evidence.
Cha Eui-jae hesitated for a long moment before finally opening his mouth.
"...I was happy."
Why were those three words so difficult to say?
His head felt hot. The inside of his mask was burning. The sound of his heartbeat was so loud it was driving him insane.
He didn't want to be caught, but at the same time, he did. He wanted Lee Sa-young to not know, but also to notice. He wanted the warmth to go away, but also for it to stay. Ironically, even Cha Eui-jae couldn't fully understand his own feelings.
Ah, this is a mess.
Cha Eui-jae raised his arms and covered the eye holes of his mask. Lee Sa-young chuckled softly, his cheek still pressed against Cha Eui-jae's chest. He looked up and gently pressed a hand to Cha Eui-jae's sternum, his voice filled with laughter.
"Why are you so loud? Even a sleeping person would wake up."
Damn it, he never lets anything go. Cha Eui-jae gritted his teeth and snapped back.
"Shut up..."
"Should I pretend I didn't notice? But I just can't..."
"Pretend you didn't."
"You know your neck is completely red, right?"
"I don't care, just shut up!"
"Shall I?"
His response was surprisingly compliant. The warmth that had been heating up Cha Eui-jae's body also began to dissipate. Cold air filled the empty space. He thought Lee Sa-young would push further, but... What was this? What was he planning? Cha Eui-jae cautiously lowered the hand that had been covering his eyes. Lee Sa-young was smiling.
"I've waited 8 years. I can wait a bit longer."
"..."
"But still."
At that moment, fingers slipped beneath the mask. With a click, it was lifted and removed. Cold air blasted against his flushed, overheated face, but only for a moment—
"Mmph—!"
The flood of words that had been waiting to spill from his lips were swallowed up. A thick tongue invaded his mouth, rubbing against his own. It felt like he was being devoured. Of all the kisses they'd shared, this one was the roughest. His lips were crushed. Somewhere between the sweetness, he tasted the metallic flavor of blood, probably from biting his lip in the moment they had briefly parted.
Even the small whimper he let out between gasps was drowned in the wet sound. Cha Eui-jae tried to push Lee Sa-young's shoulders away but slowly gave up, letting his hands fall limp. As if in praise, Lee Sa-young's tongue gently caressed the tender flesh. Cha Eui-jae's body trembled. His eyes filled with heat. The kiss finally broke when he was on the verge of suffocation.
His legs gave way, and his feet touched the ground. Cha Eui-jae clutched the railing and leaned forward, coughing harshly. Cough, cough. He looked up sharply to glare at Lee Sa-young.
But,
"You..."
"Hmm... was it too rough?"
Lee Sa-young wiped his lips with his thumb. Dark blood dripped from his swollen lips. Not mine— had I bitten him? When? I wasn't even thinking clearly enough to realize I had. A black tongue flicked out to lick away the blood.
"No matter how good it felt."
"There you go, making things up again. 'Good,' my ass..."
"Then, did you hate it?"
"..."
"You're a terrible liar."
Once Cha Eui-jae finally managed to stand straight, clutching the railing for support, Lee Sa-young snickered. His body was still overheated, but seeing blood helped clear his head a bit. Cha Eui-jae cleared his throat unnecessarily.
"Do you have a potion? Hurry up and heal."
"Hm? Wouldn't that be a waste?"
"What? The potion? You're rich. You've spent tons of magic crystals on strange machines..."
"It's not the potion I'd be wasting."
Lee Sa-young raised an eyebrow. Then, with the thumb that had been wiping his lips, he pressed down on the wound. More blood began to flow. Cha Eui-jae was shocked. Had he lost his mind? He hadn't even recovered from the nightmare where Lee Sa-young had begged to be strangled harder! Cha Eui-jae hurried over and grabbed his wrist.
"Are you insane? What are you doing!"
"Hm? It'll heal soon anyway. Why waste it?"
"Waste, my ass! You have to heal injuries immediately..."
With a shout, Cha Eui-jae rummaged through his inventory. But all he grabbed was the artisan's spear, a basilisk fang, and... ah, there it was. He held up a bottle.
What he boldly pulled out was;
[Standard Healing Potion (C)]
[Restores 10% of health when used.]
It was...
"..."
"...huh?"
What is this? Cha Eui-jae stared at the small potion, barely the size of a finger, with a bewildered expression, then let out an "ah" as he remembered.
Right, he got this as a gift back when he worked part-time at the hangover soup restaurant, after people found out he was an Awakener. It was one of those items from the "A gift box for the newly Awakened ♥" or something. Probably from that hunter who looked like a Russian bear...
Hope he's doing well.
"..."
Anyway, Cha Eui-jae glanced between the small red potion and the towering, pitch-black Lee Sa-young. A C-grade potion and an S-grade Awakened. The finger-sized potion and the huge, statue-like Lee Sa-young. Watching his actions, Lee Sa-young chuckled.
"How cute."
Damn it. Cha Eui-jae grimaced. Lee Sa-young chuckled softly again and asked, amused,
"Oh. Is that actually a real potion, not some mini accessory? You're really carrying that around?"
